title: Aussie AFL love : Seoul to regional footy tales in global newsletter | The Daily Advertiser
body_text:
A move to Korea for love hasn't stopped a self-confessed "AFL tragic" from keeping abreast of the league and taking the quirks of the game at a grassroots level and sharing them with the world.

Diana Underwood has lived in Seoul for 22 years with her American husband and said there was a thriving Australian community in Korea, which liked to organise events for occasions like Australia Day, Anzac Day, the AFL Grand Final and the Melbourne Cup.
"Many of us are AFL tragics, so I started a tipping competition called the Korea Tippers," Mrs Underwood said.
"It has been running for 17 years to engender some competitive spirit as we follow our footy clubs throughout the season.
"I began my weekly updates a few years later, reviewing all the AFL games and the movements on our comp ladder."
Mrs Underwood said she enjoyed highlighting off-field stories in particular.
"I fancied myself as a bit of a [sports journalist] Caroline Wilson - and 'Caro' loves a human footy angle," she said.
"I try to make the updates humorous and always end them with a terrible joke."
The competition through ESPN Footy Tips has 33 members, including five women.
Most have lived in Korea and still do, while others live in Iran, Saudi Arabia, the UK, Hong Kong, the Philippines and Australia.
Members include Australian Ambassadors to the Middle East, hoteliers, business people, teachers, farmers, scientists, health professionals and butchers.
"They love their footy and their clubs, and because most of them are expats, they can't get to many games," she said.
"So overseas AFL TV subscriptions and footy tipping comps keep them engaged in the sport.
"Our members support 15 clubs, but we need to recruit some Gold Coast, GWS and Sydney fans to cover all 18.
"Many of us are old school footy fans and love to reflect on our clubs' past glories, we'd also love the AFL to stop meddling with the game and just leave it alone."
Mrs Underwood's brother, Roger Wilkinson, is a farmer from Warrnambool and shares his sister's love of AFL football.
"We're both essentially country folk and love how country footy clubs bring the local community together," she said.
Mrs Underwood and Mr Wilkinson experienced that firsthand on Sunday, July 27, when they watched on as the Mangoplah Cookardinia United Eastlakes Goannas and the Ganmain Grong Grong Matong Lions went head-to-head at the Mangoplah Sportsground.
"I've collected interesting and unusual names all my life," Mrs Underwood said.
"One day, I decided to look up some funny footy team names to include in the weekly email.
"And there they were - from then on, I'd give updates on the scores and ladder positions for the MCUE Goannas and the GGGM Lions.
"Everyone now knows about both teams, but I suspect Roger and I are the only ones who could say their names in full."
Mrs Underwood was in Australia for a short visit and when she looked at the Riverina League fixture and said when she saw both teams playing each other "Roger and I knew what had to come".
"Others in the comp were keen to join us but couldn't make it," she said.
"We'd love to come back next year with a few more."
Mr Wilkinson said more than 40 years ago he was listening to the country footy results on the ABC radio and he heard MCUE mentioned.
"I knew Australia had some marvellous town names, but this was the best-named football team I had ever heard," he said.
"Since then I have followed them from a distance.
"I have been to Mangoplah and Cookardinia before but this is the first footy match I have attended here. As well as the name, I also like the fact they have an Australian animal in their name.
"It was a fantastic experience."
The pair said they "lucked out" when they approached a bloke flipping steaks on the barbecue before the game.
Mrs Underwood said Cameron Buist and Nicole Killen were very welcoming and chaperoned them all afternoon.
"We met both club presidents and took lots of photos for my Riverina trip report, which has already gone to Korea Tippers," she said.
"It was a cold and wet afternoon, but incredibly cozy under the roof with the fires going, we made sure we weren't the last car out of the car park in case we needed a tow in all the mud.
"We also visited the towns both clubs are named after and took photos of their signposts."
Mr Wilkinson said he didn't believe Mr Buist and Ms Killen went to the game expecting to host visiting strangers from southern Victoria.
"They gave us the warmest welcome into the Goannas family," he said.
"It's a small world, it turns out they are originally from our part of Victoria and know some of my neighbours.
"I was impressed by the number of volunteers helping out on the day, I'm involved in several community organisations myself, so I know how much volunteer power it takes to run an event."
"I'll definitely be back. I want another chance to wear my Goannas beanie."
Mrs Underwood said her husband Peter's great-grandparents were pioneer American missionaries to Korea in the 1880s, and he is the last member of his family still living there.
"I had known Peter's father since I was a teenager, and he was our matchmaker in 2002," she said.
"We married in 2004 in the little country church near our family farm in Wangoom, near Warrnambool.
"So I moved to Korea for love, we now live between Seoul, Melbourne and Warrnambool."
Mrs Underwood is a self-confessed Richmond tragic and knows what it is like to endure hard times, including 37 years between premierships
"I flew from Seoul to Melbourne for the 2017 and 2019 grand finals," she said.
"I had to settle for a ticket to our Punt Road ground to watch the game on a big screen, but I was lucky enough to get a ticket to the players' celebration at Crown Casino that night.
"It was the best night of my life, and I was euphoric for the best part of six months afterwards.
"Roger and I both saw them win the 2019 flag, but I was locked out of Australia for their 2020 premiership because of COVID, along with so many other Australians.
"Those three premierships will satisfy me for a very long time."
